title: World Series Game 7: Nearly everyone is available for Nationals and Astros
text:
The only player from the 50 total active tabbed as unavailable was Astros pitcher Justin Verlander, who started on Tuesday. Martinez did not rule out his Game 6 starter, Stephen Strasburg, who indicated last night he felt gassed.

“If you have a Nats uniform on today and you’re part of 25, I’m going to ask you if you can go,” said Martinez, who added, “I’m going to talk to [Strasburg] later on. Hey, there’s no tomorrow.”

AD

Martinez added catcher Kurt Suzuki, scratched from the starting lineup, could still appear. He talked to the catcher early Wednesday morning and “felt it would be best to just keep him on the bench.” The lineup shake-up was precautionary.

AD

“I like Suzuki coming off the bench if need be, to pinch-hit or even to catch,” Martinez said.

Everyone else is apparently good to go. It’s Game 7 and, in the words of Max Scherzer, let’s go.

• The commissioner discussed the Trea Turner call, the bat-carrying controversy and more.

• Nationals catcher Kurt Suzuki was supposed to be back in the starting lineup after missing the last two games with a right hip flexor strain. The 36-year-old hurt himself in Game 4 while blocking a Fernando Rodney change-up in the dirt. He was available in an emergency pinch-hit situation in Game 6, but the team never needed him and elected to let him rest up for a Game 7 start. Instead, Suzuki will not start Game 7 and Yan Gomes will catch for Max Scherzer.

AD

Lineup change for the Nationals: Kurt Suzuki has been scratched and Yan Gomes will catch Max Scherzer and hit eighth tonight. — Jesse Dougherty (@dougherty_jesse) October 30, 2019

Dave Martinez on Kurt Suzuki: He thought I’d be safer to bring Suzuki off the bench and not risk having to pull him a few innings into the game. — Jesse Dougherty (@dougherty_jesse) October 30, 2019

Suzuki and Scherzer formed one of the Nationals’ best batteries this season. His numbers with Scherzer this season: 2.08 ERA in 99 ⅔ innings pitched. Scherzer’s performance when paired with Gomes, however, has been less productive: 4.09 ERA in 72 ⅔ innings.

AD

• The Wizards — led by Juan Soto mega-fan Bradley Beal — continue to show love to the local baseball team. In an odd twist, Houston’s NBA team is in Washington for a game at the same time that Washington’s MLB team is in Houston for Game 7.

there's so much happening in this video



- rookie hazing

- support for the #Nats

- Halloween outfit because why not? https://t.co/KEuaBOprgj — Candace Buckner (@CandaceDBuckner) October 30, 2019

How to watch

Game 7: Washington Nationals at Houston Astros (Series tied, 3-3)

When: 8:07 p.m.

Where: Minute Maid Park in Houston

Starting pitchers: Max Scherzer (11-7, 2.92 ERA) vs. Zack Greinke (18-5, 2.93 ERA)

AD

Max Scherzer, too hurt to dress himself three days ago, will now start Game 7 of the World Series. The Washington Nationals ace almost appeared as a reliever in Game 6 and, after the game, he rocked slowly, slightly back and forth in front of his locker. He delivered short, curt answers, the frenetic energy inside trying to escape.

AD

How long can you go? “I should be good.”

Is this a normal start? “Game 7. Let’s go.”

Right fielder Adam Eaton joked that Scherzer was “coming back from the dead” to start Game 7, because spasms in his neck and back forced the 35-year-old to miss his scheduled Game 5 start. Now, after a cortisone shot, he’s ready to oppose the Houston Astros third ace Zack Greinke.

AD

Scherzer will lead the Nationals as close to a World Series title as this team has ever come. Their World Series hopes soared when they left Houston up 2-0, sagged when they left Washington down 3-2 and now seem strong again after a Game 6 win in which the offense awoke and Stephen Strasburg shoved. This is the first series in MLB, NBA and NHL history to see the road team win the first six games of the series — the Nationals wouldn’t mind if they extended that streak one more.

AD

Lineups

Washington Nationals

Trea Turner SS

Adam Eaton RF

Anthony Rendon 3B

Juan Soto LF

Howie Kendrick DH

Asdrúbal Cabrera 2B

Ryan Zimmerman 1B

Victor Robles CF

Max Scherzer P

AD

Michael Brantley LF

Alex Bregman 3B

Yordan Alvarez DH

Carlos Corea SS

Robinson Chirinos C

Josh Reddick RF

Zack Greinke P

Game 7 reading

When it comes to pitching strategy, Game 7 of the World Series brings chaos theory to life. Just about every pitcher for the Nationals and Astros will be on high alert, knowing they could be called upon to pitch in the deciding game Wednesday night. (Read more)

AD

AD

How did the Nats respond to a controversial call? By leaving absolutely no doubt. A controversial interference call. Dominance from Stephen Strasburg. Booming home runs to turn it around. And now, one game to decide it all. (Read more)

Juan Soto copies Alex Bregman’s bat carry after Game 6 home run. If the Nationals didn’t have enough fueling them in an elimination Game 6 of the World Series, that they took exception to Bregman’s antics showed on Juan Soto’s home run in the fifth inning. (Read more)

AD

AD

Nationals force World Series Game 7 with dominant Stephen Strasburg performance in 7-2 win. Washington Manager Dave Martinez was ejected over a controversial call, but Strasburg nearly pitched a complete game to make Wednesday’s Game 7 a reality. (Read more)

AD

All games on Fox

· Game 2 at Houston — Nationals 12, Astros 3

· Game 3 at Washington — Astros 4, Nationals 1

· Game 4 at Washington — Astros 8, Nationals 1

· Game 5 at Washington — Astros 7, Nationals 1

· Game 6 at Houston — Nationals 7, Astros 2

AD

· Game 7 at Houston — Wednesday, Oct. 30, 8:08 p.m.

description: The Nationals have their ace Max Scherzer, back from injury, on the mound against Zack Greinke.
